subject: Re: [junit] Re: Are you really using JUnit during your development?
msgSnippet: Go not to the elves for council for they will answer both yes and no! Errr, Kent, do you have pointy ears? :-) Simon ... -- www.simonpeter.org
messageBody:
"Go not to the elves for council for they will answer both yes and no!"

Errr, Kent, do you have pointy ears? :-)

Simon

On 8/8/06, Kent Beck <kentb@...> wrote:
> One factor that complicates this discussion (besides the overall lack of
> civility) is that tools, techniques, and culture are changing quickly. When
> person A says, "You can't test everything," and person B says, "Yes, you
> can," they can both be right from their perspective if person B has access
> to tools or techniques that person A does not. The cultural aspect of
> developer testing that further muddies the waters is that the global
> develoment community is changing quickly but unevenly. Once again, person A
> can say, "You ought to write tests," and person B can say, "You don't need
> to write tests," and they can both be correct from their perspective. More
> precisely, one person could say, "I think it is my duty as a programmer to
> write thorough, automated tests," and the other say, "I think testing is one
> of many priorities that need to be balanced so it is my duty as a programmer
> to sometimes skip writing automated tests," and they could both be
> expressing valid opinions.
>
> Yours,
>
> Kent Beck
> Three Rivers Institute


--
www.simonpeter.org
